sections.description: This section offers a number of resources for designers, developers and other who might be interested in the process of design and development of digital design solutions at Scania. It offers high level resources such as, defnitions and way of working for deign and development teams, as well as downloadable resources such as UI design kit and various resources for development.

Scania Digital Design System is designed to assist designers in their everyday work at Scania at various levels. For example, if you are interested in making yourself aware of the building blocks (e.g. principles and guidelines) of Digital Design at Scania, please refer to [Foundations](foundation). If you are looking for design patterns (components) please refer to [Components](components). And of course, Scania Digital Design System offers a UI design kit (in Adobe XD format at the moment) that can be downloaded to speed up your work.

As you can imagine, such resources are in constant need of ugradation and therefore the Scania Design System encourages [contribution](contribution) from Scania design community.

Would you like to contribute to the contents of the Scania Digital Design System? If so, you are more than welcome to reach out to us in our [Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3a1257007a64d44c64954acca27a9d4b46%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=79f9bfeb-73e2-424d-9477-b236191ece5e&tenantId=3bc062e4-ac9d-4c17-b4dd-3aad637ff1ac) or directly to [Marcus Åström](mailto:marcus.astrom@scania.com) .
Buttons are a mode for inputting user action for communicating user’s intention.
Buttons are not the same as links – links are not input modes but it is a mode for navigation – from one page to another page or from one view to another view.

<button type='button' class='btn btn-primary'>Primary</button>
<button type='button' class='btn btn-secondary'>Secondary</button>
<button type='button' class='btn btn-success'>Success</button>
<button type='button' class='btn btn-danger'>Danger</button>

- **Solid button**: meant for primary action, solid filled to attract user’s attention
- **Outline button**: meant for secondary action and to compliment primary action
- **Flat button**: meant for tertiary action

Two distinct patterns can be used to place buttons

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/be1d256a05024ad98ce2143b6fc6486d.PNG)

**Z Pattern**

The Z pattern is one of the more common trajectories followed by users when going through the content. For this reason, the core of the content is positioned at the top left side and the call for action is located on the right bottom side. This pattern holds true for languages that are read from left to right. The patterns works in the reverse manner for the languages that are read from right to left.

**F pattern**

The F pattern is a variation of Z pattern where the core of the content is situated on the left top and the call for action is located on the left bottom. The pattern is reversed for languages that are read from right to left.

 
 **Interaction Pattern**

Buttons to simulate clicking action that is visualised by means of change in colour/shade

**Compositional Pattern (with Style Guide)**

Style of buttons to follow the style guide in the following manner - 

The text inside of buttons to be always UPPERCASE. Descriptive language relating to the intent of the user should be used to formulate button text.

*Colour*

Primary colour to provide consistency across all applications - **Scania Blue**

Action based colour to provide an all clear message or a warning to the user - **green or red**

Disabled button colour – **grey**

*Icons*

Icons – that clearly communicate the intent for action – can be used in place of text for a button
When icons are accompanied with text, it follows the icon (i.e. icon first and then the text)

Title attribute – a tooltip to be visible when hovering a button (where necessary). The text is displayed below the button.

Icons can be used with any kind of buttons mentioned above.
<button type='button' class='btn btn-primary'>Primary</button>
<button type='button' class='btn btn-secondary'>Secondary</button>
<button type='button' class='btn btn-success'>Success</button>
<button type='button' class='btn btn-warning'>Warning</button>
<button type='button' class='btn btn-danger'>Danger</button>
<button type='button' class='btn btn-info'>Info</button>
A dropdown is a type of menu that presents a list of option to the user and allows them to choose one of more to take action

Separated link

-	Use a button to toggle the menu. The button can be labelled with text or an icon that is easy to understand.
-	Menu items to be ordered by usage
-	make sure that the text is short and concise. Long menus are truncated with ellipsis added
-	Nested menus can be used when necessary – up to three levels.
-	disable menu(s) if needed

Welcome to the Scania Digital Design System!

The Scania Digital Design System has been designed to aid and support conceptualization and realization of digital solution across all of Scania. For this purpose, the Scania Digital Design System is constituted of the following key sections:

1. The Foundations: a resource for principles and style guide that are considered as the foundations for conceptualization of digital design solutions.

2. The Components: a resourse for design patterns that are considered as the nuts and bolts of digital design solutions.

3. The Resources: a collection of knowledge assets, tools and downloadable assets to aid design and development of digital solutions.

As you can imagine, such resources are in constant need of upgradation and therefore the Scania Design System encourages [contribution](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/contribution) from Scania design and development community. The guardians of the Scania Digital Design System are more than happy to [support](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/support) Scania teams for their design and development tasks so please feel free to reach out to us.

The Scania Digital Design System is the single source of truth to be used as a resource to aid the process of conceptualization and realization of digital design and development projects/initiatives across all of Scania. It consists of information that would be valuable for managers, designers and as well developers who are involved in planning, designing and development of degital design projects/initiatives with the purpose to bring in sustained optimal velocity in implementation and consistency across all kinds of digital solutions.

We look forward to your feedback!

Included here are some of the most frequently asked questions and their answers about the Scania Digital Design System and its contents. FAQs address both design and development related questions (and answers) which are organised in seperate sections. The FAQ section is upgraded on an ongoing basis so please reach out to us if you have questions that you think should be included here.

## Design

Design involves solving a problem by proposing a solution

## Solution

A "solution" is a product or combination of products or a service that is customized for solving a problem from a user’s perspective

**Product**

A product is a system of physical and/or digital components that is customized for user’s needs

**Service**

A service is a system of people, processes, and products that is customized for user’s needs

## Human Centered Design

Design approach to systems design and development that aims to make interactive systems more usable by focusing on the use of the system and applying human factors/ergonomics and usability knowledge and techniques

*from ISO 9241:210-2019*

## UX design

Design to shape user’s perceptions and responses that result from the use and/or anticipated use of a system, product or service

*from ISO 9241:210-2019*

## UI design

Design of all components of an interactive system (software or hardware) that provide information and controls for the user to accomplish specific tasks with the interactive system

*from ISO 9241:210-2019*

## Service Design
	
Design of a system of people, processes, and products that is customized for user’s needs
The grid fundamental to our design system. It provides structure and guidance for all creative decision-making. And for the end user.

## 4 px baseline grid ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/d09a7858b21d4717b1e1e0e365bb196f.svg)
## The basic unit

The grid is based on a 4 px baseline grid. All type aligns to this grid. All line-heights of the fonts used are divisible by 4.

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/a03f6614c1c8479f8357dc7539fa01ca.svg)

## The pixel grid

The basic unit forms a 4 px (1 REM) square grid. Every UI element should align with the pixel grid.

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/57a416c37925449186fb76cbcedbc496.svg)
## Spacing

Multiples of the basic unit form a spacing scale. It contains small increments of space needed to create appropriate spatial relationships for detail-level designs. Use the spacing scale when building individual components and deciding spaces between them. Every part of a UI should be intentional, including the space between elements. The amount of space between items creates relationships and hierarchy.

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/d9790147d47643948d66dc2159e28257.svg)

-	Listgroups should make it possible for users to take action.
-	List groups should use text and images and a consistent manner.

## Two levels of way of working

### 1. Way of working between the UX design team and the Agile development team



It is recommended that UX design stage precedes Agile development stage. In practice, the UX design stage is recommended to be carried out at two levels. One, at meta level where the information architecture (IA) of the solution is carried out and finalized in collaboration with the development team. At the same time, this stage of UX design also delivers detailed wireframes, including the behaviour of the interactive elements, that are evaluated with the intended users. Once this is finalised, it provides the vision for the development team. The development team then breaks down the vision in terms of epics, stories and sub tasks and prioritize them for development. Two, at micro level, where UX design team details out the wireframes – for the epic/story prioritised for development - and provides UI specifications for development. This stage of UX design works in parallel with development and provides continuous contribution as required by the epic/story. Once an epic/story is implemented and tested, the UX design team, moves on to the next sprint/development stage and repeats above mentioned tasks based on the epic/story. This continues until the end of the project.

### 2.The way of working within the UX team UX team is, ideally, a multidisciplinary team with its members coming from a variety of disciplines, such as, design, computer science, graphic design, psychology, anthropology, sociology etc. It is not always the case that the UX design team will have this kind of diversity. At the same time, it is common for UX designers (through their education and experience) to have a good level of competence (originating from a variety of fields, such as sociology, design etc.) to run all aspects of the UX design process. Given this, the UX design team should assess their competencies via a vis UX various stages of UX design process (such as, research, design, prototyping and evaluation) and assign responsibilities of conducting each such stages amongst themselves. The UX design process, then, is carried out iteratively, in a sprint like fashion. That is, when the first cycle of UX design process constituting of research, design, prototyping and evaluation is complete and reflected upon (to access if the solution arrived at meets the needs of the intended users), another cycle of UX design process is carried out and the same is repeated until the solution arrived at addresses the needs of the intended users in the best possible manner and at an optimum cost.

A footer is a key element of a web-based application/site. It is located at the bottom of the page and is amongst the last elements of the page. Footer, in most cases, constituted of tirtiary links, such as, contact into, location, support links etc., the copyright into and the last update date for the solution.

This section elaborates upon the basic building blocks of digital design solutions at Scania. The section includes an overview of UX and UI principles and an elaborate discussion on the elements of Style Guide aligned with the Scania Brand Guidelines.

UX design is concerned with shaping user’s perceptions and responses that result from the use and/or anticipated use of a system, product or service. This involves a variety of tasks that are carried out at different stages, before and during the design process. Informning such tasks are the following key principles.

### User/Human Centered Design

User/Human-centered design is about creating products that will bring value to the users and the business. It is the users who will interact with the proposed product/solution, and it is the job of the designer to know the potential target audience. Designers must conduct user research to get a sense of user needs, wants, and behaviours as the first step of the design process.
At the same time, it is vital to Keep the user in control with updated system status, direct and effective UI manipulations, instant feedbacks and expectable interactions and outcomes.

### KISS (Keep It Simple Stupid)

KISS is a fundamental user interface design principle. Users will feel most comfortable if they can use the product without putting in much efforts.

### Autonomy

Users perceive that they are always in control when interacting with the product/solution.

- Enable users to make their own decisions (e.g. with respect to navigation/interaction) when interacting with the product/solution
- Use status indicators to keep users aware and informed
- Keep status information up to date and easy to view and comprehend
- Ensure that status information is accurate

### Efficiency of the User

- The efficiency in a product/solution is a result of the fundamental architecture of the system, not in the surface design of the interface
- User Error messages that help users in making sense of the status of the product/solution

### Aesthetics

Users often perceive aesthetically pleasing design as design that’s more usable.

- Aesthetic design should be left to those schooled and skilled in its application: Graphic/visual designers
- Cosmetics should never trump usability
- Conduct user test the visual design as thoroughly as the behavioural design

### Simplicity

- Use progressive revelation of the UI to flatten the learning curve
- Simplification does not mean elimination of necessary capabilities

### Learnability: take advantage of user’s familiarity

- Jacob’s law - take advantages of user’s previous knowledge (existing mental models): Users spend most of their time on other sites. This means that users prefer your site to work the same way as all the other sites they already know.

### Consistency
 
*A. Levels of Consistency*

Think of consistency at various levels. For example

1. Top level consistency
  - Platform consistency:  Consistent with guidelines and standards 
  - In-house consistency:  Consistent with look & feel across your products/services 
2. Consistency across a suite of products, e. g., Microsoft Office. General look & feel communicates across the family of a product/solution
3. The overall look & feel of a single app, application or service–splash screens, design elements, etc.
4. Small visible structures, such as icons, symbols, buttons, scroll bars, etc.
5. Invisible elements

Objects that convey information, rather than being used to generate information, should not be made invisible

*B. Induced Inconsistency*

- visual consistency should be tied up with behaviour of the UI elements. i.e., be visually consistent when UI elements behave in the same manner and inconsistent when UI elements behave differently.

*C. Consistency with User Expectation*

- Be consistent with expectations of the users of the product/solution

### Reduce short-term memory load (cognitive load)

As human short term memory is only capable of retaining 5 to 7 items at a given time, make sure that this is incorporated judiciously into UI design.

### Forgiveness

- Must ensure that users never lose their work – permit reversal of action
Error handling
- Any errors should be communicated in a human centred manner

-	Progress elements need to be animated to convey the sense of progress.

UI design is concerned with design of all components of an interactive system (software or hardware) that provide information and controls for the user to accomplish specific tasks with the interactive system. This involves a variety of tasks that are carried out at different stages, before and during the design process. Informing such tasks are the following key principles.

### Readability

- Text to be read should have high contrast and adequate line spacing
- Choice of fonts and font sizes should be made with consideration of readability vis a vis size of the display 
- Test all designs on your oldest expected user population

### Discoverability

- If the user cannot find it, it does not exist
- Use AD (Active Discovery) to guide people to more advanced features
- UI elements necessary for the successful use of product/solution should be visibly accessible at all times
- Communicate your gestural vocabulary with visual diagrams
- Strive for Balance
- User-test for discoverability

### Explorable Interfaces

- Give users well-marked navigational structure
- Offer users stable perceptual cues for a sense of “home”
- Make Actions reversible or Always allow “Undo”
- Always allow a way out
- Make it easy and attractive to stay in

### Clarity

Clarity is the one of the key features of a UI. As per Ben Shneiderman for an interface to be effective and user-friendly, it must be recognizable, predictable, and have an obvious purpose.

### State

- As many of browser-based products/solutions exist in a stateless environment, tracking status must be designed in a suitable manner 
- Make clear to the user regarding the information that will stored & and that it will be protected

### Feedback

- Provide timely and contextually-relevant feedback to the user.
- Feedback can be visual, auditory or haptic as required.

### Latency Reduction

Keep users informed when they face delay

### Anticipation

- Make visible to the user all UI elements needed for each step of the process

### Use of Metaphors

- Choose metaphors that will enable users to comprehend the finest details of the conceptual model of the product/solution
- Must go beyond literal interpretation of real-world counterparts

### Human Interface Objects

- Human-interface objects are easy to perceive and act upon
- Human-interface objects have a standard way of being manipulated
- Human-interface objects have standard resulting behaviours
- Use a new object when a new modality of interaction is introduced

### Purposeful page layout

- Be judicious about the  spatial relationships between items on the page and structure the page based on importance.

### Visible Navigation

- Make navigation visible
- Limit number of navigation items by using overlays

### Colour

*Colour blindness*

- When colour is used to convey information in the interface, use clear, secondary cues to convey the information to those who cannot see the colours presented.
- Test your site to see with colour blind users

*Colour as a vital interface element*

- User colour judiciously in UI

### Fitts’s Law

- The time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target
- Fitts’s Law is in effect regardless of the kind of pointing device or the nature of the target
- Fitts’s Law requires a stop watch test

### Law of common region 

Elements tend to be perceived into groups if they located within a clearly defined boundary.

### Law of Proximity

Objects that are proximate to each other tend to be grouped together.

### Miller’s Law
The average person can only keep 7 (plus or minus 2) items in their working memory.


The Von Restorff effect, also known as The Isolation Effect, predicts that when multiple similar objects are present, the one that differs from the rest is most likely to be remembered.

Alerts are banners/modals that communicate a message with a degree of urgency attached to it.

There are two key types of alerts: *standard alerts* and *application level alerts*

Standard alerts are to be designed to garb user’s attention to provide critical information needed in a context of use.

Standard alerts are of four types: *Success, Information, Warning and Error*

**Usage Pattern: standard alerts**

- A banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that the action taken by them have been successful.
A simple success alert—check it out!

- The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that additional information is available about the context of use.
A simple info alert—check it out!

- The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that the action taken by them have resulted in a warning with respect to the context of use.
A simple warning alert—check it out!

- The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that the action taken by them have resulted in an error with respect to the context of use.
A simple danger alert—check it out!

Standard alerts convey severity and urgency in the following order: error, warning, info and success.

In case there are multiple subtypes (of each of the types mentioned above) all of them are shown before another standard alert type is shown. For example – multiple error warnings are shown before a warning alert is shown.

Standard alerts could be place in multiple contexts including inside of components. 

**Application level alerts**

Application level alerts are of three types: *Error, Warning and Information*

**Usage Pattern: application level alerts**

Application level alerts follow the same order as standard level alerts: Error, Warning and Information.
A simple success alert—check it out!
A simple warning alert—check it out!
A simple info alert—check it out!
A simple danger alert—check it out!
Design patterns are templates of recurring solutions that solve common design problems.

Design patterns can be divided into three types:

- **Compositional design patterns**
- **Interaction design patterns**
- **Compositional design patterns**

Composition here refers to coming together of, one, UI elements and Style guide elements (such as button with typography or an image) and two, combination of two or more such micro level compositions into a larger whole (i.e. from atoms to molecules to organisms). Such compositions can vary from, for example, a page on the higher side of complexity to a button on the lower side of complexity. 

Compositional design patterns, then, provide templates of recurring solutions to such common compositional problems.

Included in the Scania Design System so far (first version) are compositional design patterns associated with UI elements. 

These design patterns are part of usage guidelines for the following UI elements (first version).

Alert, Badge, Breadcrumbs, Button, Button group, Cards, Dropdown, Forms, Input groups, List groups, Loading, Media Objects, Modals, Navs, Pagination, Progress, Tables

## Interaction Design patterns

Interaction refers to the interaction between the user and the user interface. Interaction is constituted of action from the user’s side and the response or feedback from the system’s side. Both, i.e. action from user’s side and the response or feedback from the system’s side are externalised by behaviour of UI elements as well as the compositional elements.

Interaction design patterns, then, provide templates for recurring solutions to user/human computer interaction pertaining to behaviour of UI elements and components that solve common interaction problems.

**Example**

*Interaction design pattern for Buttons (accompanied with animation)*

Toggle buttons

*Interaction with mouse*

When interacted with mouse, button appears to be pressed down – visually – and the interaction is accompanied by a sound (this can vary from case to case basis). The pressed down state of the button is articulated by active colour. This interaction pattern repeats itself when user interacts with the button again to toggle the button off.

*Interaction with touchscreen/touchpad*

When tapped, the button appears to be pressed down – visually – and the interaction is accompanied by a sound (this can vary from case to case basis). The pressed down state of the button is articulated by active colour. This interaction pattern repeats itself when user interacts with the button again to toggle the button off.

## Usage patterns

Usage patterns refer to template of recurring solution with respect to use of a UI element or a compositional element. The usage pattern is also extended to common functional features, e.g. copy, edit, save, delete etc.

Logotype is a graphic representation of a company name or initials that is designed conscuiusly to reflect values and attributes associated with the company. Logotype is not the same as logomark which is a graphic representation, in form of a symbolic image or icon, of the company.

For usage, first download Scania Symbol or Scania Wordmark or both (as the case may be)

Forms is a modality of collecting inputs from the user and submitting it to an application.
We'll never share your email with anyone else.

-	Forms are constituted of text and input elements such as, checkboxes, dropdowns, radio buttons, toggle switches etc. Forms should be clear and concise to make it easy for users to complete forms.
-	Use one column to organise the form. 
-	Group input elements that are similar. This makes it easy for users to scan them.
-	Forms should not be longer than a page – ideally. However, if a forms need to be longer, use pagination.
-	Forms must let users know when something is wrong with the information provided. Error message styling, content and location should make it easy for users to understand where they have made errors (exact styling to be decided).
-	Both real-time as well as after post validation can be done as appropriate.
We'll never share your email with anyone else.

Buttons groups are collection of same type of buttons.

-	Solid button group: meant for primary action, solid filled to attract user’s attention
-	Outline button group: meant for secondary action and to compliment primary action
-	Flat button group: meant for tertiary action
-	Disabled button group: meant to prevent users from sending inputs accidently, also meant to prevent input till conditions for the input are met.
Button groups follow button design guidelines. Button groups can be constituted of the following:

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/a2cccee7a5614a3eb1bbc18d18452483.PNG)

Mixing actions

**Do** – Locate primary action on the left, followed by secondary and warning action.

**Don’t** – Located warning action on the left.

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/6818a75bf625462eb823f003161177d2.PNG)

Mixing styles

**Do**– group buttons that are styled in a similar manner – such as, primary and tertiary types

**Don’t**– group button that are styles in a different manner – such as primary and secondary types

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/24c96ddfa99d423281bf2a04341d8747.PNG)

Icons - Types and sizes

**Do**– Icons can be used with all types of buttons. However, make sure that the buttons are large size (36px)

**Don’t** – use small size buttons with icons

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/aa70aa1bae5542798493a3b4e83eb402.PNG)

**Do**– text is useful with icons as they helps users. When used, icons should be followed by text

**Don’t** – follow text by icons

To be used when the button group is larger than space available or there is intention to save space. In such cases, an ellipsis button is included in the button group that shows the overflow drop down menu.

Interaction

Clicking on ellipsis button will bring up a dropdown menu

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/1ca911fc81dc452fa8ba4ec7b4aabb30.PNG)

Follow the pattern of use of icons and text for buttons in this case.

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/0183ac6194cb4cd6b558f26bd1e49086.PNG)

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/5997dc1f699a41ecbbd5f5a65668959e.PNG)

**Do** – primary actions are followed by secondary action

**Don’t** – secondary actions followed by primary action

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/c8704217c8c94c64817ef15c2d7e43ff.PNG)

**Do** – use short labels ( 1 to 3 words)

**Don’t** – use labels that are longer than 3 words.

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/61d3a3994ad5447ba954238302e58a9d.PNG)

**Do** – use short labels ( 1 to 3 words)

**Don’t** – use labels that are longer than 3 words.

Do you need help within development or with Components? Please reach out in [Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3a1257007a64d44c64954acca27a9d4b46%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=79f9bfeb-73e2-424d-9477-b236191ece5e&tenantId=3bc062e4-ac9d-4c17-b4dd-3aad637ff1ac) or report a [bug](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose) or a [Feature request](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new?assignees=&labels=Feature&template=feature_request.md&title=Feature+-+%22title+text%22) in our Development GitHub.

Need help within the design area? We can't design your application for you but we'll happily guide you through how you can use the different sections and tools in the Scania Digital Design System. Please get in touch with us through [Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3a1257007a64d44c64954acca27a9d4b46%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=79f9bfeb-73e2-424d-9477-b236191ece5e&tenantId=3bc062e4-ac9d-4c17-b4dd-3aad637ff1ac) and we'll do our best to help out.

## About the Scania Digital Design System

<details>
    <summary>What is Scania Digital Design System?</summary>
    <section>A design system is primarily a repository of UI elements, components and patterns informed by Scania Digital Branding Guidelines. In addition, it also includes sections on UX and UI principles, ways of working, governance etc. as well as downloadable resources such as, Scania UI toolkit, Corporate UI, etc.</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>What is Scania Digital Design System used for?</summary>
    <section>Scania Digital Design System provides code of its primary content, such as, UI elements, components and patterns that can be downloaded and used to reduce time needed for design and development of digital solutions at Scania. At the same time, use of Scania Digital Design System ensures that digital solutions designed and developed at Scania are consistent with respect to their look and feel and that they follow Scania Digital Branding guidelines.

The system can be used for a wide range of digital application. For now, the scope of the design system is limited to web based portals. In future, it will be extended to support wide variety of application in Scania.
The system can also be used to build awareness about UX and UI design and learn about do’s and don’ts. </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>What are the benefits of the Scania Digital Design System?</summary>
    <section>The design system offers a number of benefits. For designers, it provides the “single source of truth” and avoids potential creation of accidental design variations leading to brand inconsistencies. For developers, it reduces time to code as UI elements, components and patterns can be downloaded from the design system. For the company as a whole, it ensures consistent user experience across the breadth of digital solution at Scania and makes it easier for users to navigate and engage with.</section>
</details>

## Getting Started

<details>
    <summary>Is Scania Digital Design System accessible outside the Scania network?</summary>
    <section>Yes. Scania Digital Design System is accessible here http://digitaldesign.scania.com.</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Is Scania Digital Design System available on mobile platform?</summary>
    <section>Not at the moment. But we are working on it and we will make it available on mobile platforms in near future.</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>What are the contents of the Scania Digital Design System?</summary>
    <section>Scania Digital Design System is constituted of -

1.	UI elements, components and patterns
2.	Foundations ( UX and UI principles and elements of Style Guide)
3.	Resources (e.g. UI kit, Corporate UI and other goodies)

    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Who are the users of the Scania Digital Design System?</summary>
    <section>All stakeholders of digital design solutions designed and developed in Scania are envisaged as the users of the Scania Digital Design System.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>What is the difference between UI elements, components and patterns?</summary>
    <section>The classification of UI elements, components and patterns is based on atomic design principles. That is, UI elements are seen as singular elements, UI components are seen as composite elements (consisting of one or more UI elements and elements of Style guide) and patterns are seen as organisms or modules, that provide a template. See the section on Components and patterns of the Scania Digital Design System.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I download code from the design system?</summary>
    <section>Code can be copied directly from the website.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>What kind of resources can be accessed from the design system?</summary>
    <section>For now, Scania UI Kit and Corportate UI are the two key resources that can be accessed from the design system. We plan to add more resources in future.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Who works on the Scania Digital Design System?</summary>
    <section>The Corporate Digital Design team (IXCD) works as the owners of Scania Digital Design System. The team collaborates with various teams across Scania as and when required.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How can I contribute to the Scania Digital Design System?</summary>
    <section>Please visit this link to contribute - https://digitaldesign.scania.com/contribution
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I report anything that is missing or suggest any improvements?</summary>
    <section>Please reach out to us in our teams channel or contact Marcus Åstrom directly.
    </section>
</details>

## Foundations

<details>
    <summary>What are the contents of the foundations of the Scania Digital Design System?</summary>
    <section>The foundation section is constituted of UX and UI principles and the guidelines on the elements of Scania Style Guide. Please visit the foundation section (https://digitaldesign.scania.com/foundation) to learn more.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I apply UX principles?</summary>
    <section>UX principles are based on the best practices of design and are applied to various aspects of a solution during its conceptual development. Please get in touch with the Scania Digital Design Team for further questions.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I apply UI principles?</summary>
    <section>UI principles are based on the principles of Cognitive Design and are applied to various aspects of a solution during its conceptual development. Please get in touch with the Scania Digital Design Team for further questions.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I contribute to UX and UI principles repository?</summary>
    <section>Please visit this link to contribute - https://digitaldesign.scania.com/contribution
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I work with grids and spacings?</summary>
    <section>Please visit this link - https://digitaldesign.scania.com/foundation/grid-and-spacing
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I download fonts and icons?</summary>
    <section>It is not possible to download fonts and icons from the Scania Digital Design System at the moment. But the team is working on it to make this possible in near future.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Are there any guidelines for creation of icons that are not included in the design system?</summary>
    <section>Guidelines for creation of icons have not been formulated so far. But the team is working on it to make it available in near future.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Who do I contact regarding help with style guide?</summary>
    <section>Please reach out to us in our teams channel or contact directly Marcus Åstrom directly.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I report anything that is missing or suggest any improvements?</summary>
    <section>Please reach out to us in our teams channel or contact Marcus Åstrom directly.
    </section>
</details>

## Components

<details>
    <summary>How do I use a UI component for my design prototype?</summary>
    <section>Using a UI component for design requires Scania UI kit that can be downloaded from the Scania Digital Design System. Should you require further assistance, please get in touch with the team or contact Marcus Åstrom directly.

<details>
    <summary>I want to modify look and feel of a UI element. Is it possible?</summary>

## Resources

<details>
    <summary>What are resources?</summary>
    <section>Scania Digital Design System views resources as assets, tools, kits, knowledge resources etc. that help us in the process of design and development of a digital solution at Scania.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I use resources provided by the design system?</summary>

The Scania UI toolkit which can be downloaded from the design systems website and can be used for prototyping during the design phase. For development, the design system offers the Corporate UI which can be accessed at - https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui

    </section>

    </section>

    <summary>How do I report anything that is missing or suggest any improvements?</summary>

## Support

<details>
    <summary>What are the topics for which I can seek support?</summary>

<details>
    <summary>What is Corporate UI?</summary>
    <section>Corporate-UI is framework, based on stencilJS, which provide a UI toolbox to use in your application. All components are Web-components and follow the web-component standard in the browser.</section>
</details>


<details>
  <summary>What is Scania-Theme?</summary>
  <section>Scania-Theme is a package built with CSS(SASS) to style every component according to Scania identity guidelines</section>
</details>


<details>
  <summary>What is a web-component?</summary>
  <section>Web-components are a standard for creating elements that you can use in your application. One standard component that is using the same technology is the <video></video> element. If you look at it with “shadow-dom show” enabled in your settings, you can see it is more than just video elements inside it. One example component in Corporate-UI that is a web-component is the c-header. Web-components consist of:

- Custom-elements
- Shadow DOM
- HTML templates

You can read more about it here: [Link](https://auth0.com/blog/creating-web-components-with-stencil/)</section>
</details>


<details>
    <summary>Is there any documentation or list of components?</summary>
    <section>

You can find documentation of components here: [Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components)
</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Where do I find the Experimental components and patterns?</summary>
    <section>

We are planning to add all experimental components and pattern into Scania Digital Design System site later. Right now it is not possible to see component that is under development. You can check [corporate-ui repository](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui) to see our current backlog and components that are being developed in the moment.</section>
</details>


<details>
  <summary>What should I do if I find a component that isn’t accessible?</summary>
  <section>Contact our team</section>
</details>


<details>
  <summary>Where can I get help implementing the components with my project?</summary>
  <section>

Read how to use components in the [getting started section](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development) </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Is there Dark mode in Corporate-UI? </summary>
    <section>Right now, no. But this is something that is highly demanded. The reason why we haven’t added is that it needs a lot for research before something like that can be implemented</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>I need a new icon, how do I add it?</summary>
    <section>

- First, check if icon is available [here](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/foundation/icons)
- Icon that has been included in Scania Media Provider but not available in Corporate UI: Create a [feature request](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose) with detail information about the icon that you need.
- New icon: Contact our team for more information.

</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Are there .psd or .sketch files of the components?</summary>
    <section>

[Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/resources/ui-kits)</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Can I use custom bootstrap javascript plugin such as modal, tooltip, carousel together with Corporate-ui? </summary>
    <section>
      Yes.  We have bootstrap plugin script built in Corporate UI. You can access them by enabling global attribute in c-theme component.

<c-theme name='scania' global='true'></c-theme>

It is important to listen to 'bsReady' event before initiating bootstrap plugin. An example how to use it:

document.addEventListener('bsReady', function(event) {
CorporateUi.$('#modalMoveSelected').modal('hide')
});</section>

</details>

<details>
  <summary>Who can use the components?</summary>
  <section>Developers, with somewhat understanding of front-end development for all web based application</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>Which browsers are supported?</summary>
  <section>All Major ones. IE, Chrome FF and Edge, with polyfills if needed</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>What JavaScript frameworks are supported?</summary>
  <section>Angular, React and Vue. More might come in the future.

[See live examples](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/resources/development).
</section>
</details>


<details>
  <summary>Can I use corporate-ui on third party application?</summary>
  <section>Third part application is very limited support, due to every third-party application is built differently. If you know you can import libraries and so on, please try it out!</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>Why did you stop supporting font-awesome pro? </summary>
  <section>We took the decision to start creating and using our own Scania icons. You can still use font-awesome pro, but you need to buy your own licence.</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>Is it possible to migrate from Corporate-ui 3 to 4?</summary>
  <section>

Yes, it is! It will take some effort, but that is how all upgrades are when it is a major one. You can read more about it in our migration guide ([Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development)). One thing to remember is that, not everything that was in Corporate-UI 3 will be in 4. We have removed and/or changed some components and dependencies that we had, for example upgrade bootstrap 3 to 4.

</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>What are the differences between version three and version four?</summary>
    <section>
      One of the key things that changed are:

- Moved from polymer to stencilJS
- Upgrade from Bootstrap 3 to 4
- How you import a component
- Scania-theme is added for styling components
- Removed Font-awesome Pro support
- Not using BootstrapNativeJS for JS support in bootstrap

[Read migration guideline here](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development)
    </section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>What are the major changes Bootstrap 3 to 4?</summary>
  <section>

You can see what are the major changes in bootstrap 3 to 4 in bootstraps own documentation. For example Panel component have been removed and replaced by cards. [Link](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.4/migration/)
</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>I haven’t updated to the latest version of Corporate UI yet, and I still need the old documentation. Where can I find it?</summary>
    <section>

[Visit documentation for Corporate UI 3](https://scania.github.io/corporate-ui-docs/)
</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>Will you add every component that bootstrap 4 have?</summary>
  <section>We will add component that has been requested and had a good reason to be added in.</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I modify a components styling, structure or functionality ? </summary>
    <section>Depending what part of the components you want to modify:

- Styling: Corporate-UI for base component and Scania-theme
- Structure: Corporate-UI
- Functionality: Corporate-UI

</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>I need a new component, who do I talk to? </summary>
  <section>

Corporate UI is an open source and collaborative project. It means you can develop your own component and make a pull-request to add it as a part of Corporate UI. [See contributing guidelines here]( https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
If you cannot make your own component, you can add a feature request in our Github page : [Link to Github](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose) or contact our team</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>How do I make a pull request? What branch should I pull request into?</summary>
  <section>

[Read contribution guideline](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>How do I debug? </summary>
  <section>

- Investigate the cause of your problem from the development window. Go to the browser, and press *Ctr+Shift+I*. Check console tab, and see the error message.
- Version: First of you need to know which version you are using, maybe the problem is solved in later version. Look at the HTML TAG
- Styling/CSS/SASS problem: Look if anything is overriding our/your css first depending what you except.
- Crashing: If there is any error what files is it coming from? Try and investigate, remove Corporate-UI/Scania-theme dependencies see if the error still occurs or maybe upgrade?
- If you still can’t see the solution either report in [Github](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose) or ask in [team channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3a1257007a64d44c64954acca27a9d4b46%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=79f9bfeb-73e2-424d-9477-b236191ece5e&tenantId=3bc062e4-ac9d-4c17-b4dd-3aad637ff1ac) for support

</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I see which version of Corporate-UI I’m using?</summary>
    <section>

You can see that in the HTML tag , NPM package you installed and in the script if you are using CDN.
![Corporate UI version](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/4607f69014b24c45bd78c4b4f053b8ed.png)
</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>I see a bug. How do I report it?</summary>
  <section>

You can report in [Github](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose)</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>What can I expect for a response to my bug report?</summary>
  <section>

Our team will try to help fix the bug as soon as possible depends on the severity of the bug. If you know the solution, you can contribute and add the solution to corporate-ui by creating a pull-request. Please provide a detail information or an idea for the solution when you report an issue. This will make the the bug can be solved faster.  [Read contribution guideline](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).</section>
</details>

A header is a key element of a web-based application/site. It is located at the top of the page and is amongst the first elements of the page. Header, in most cases, constituted of the logo, the title of the solution, the navigational links and links for user log in. In this sense, it is seen as a defining element of the page.
global
Configurator
Configurator

Breadcrumbs are a navigational element to support wayfinding. It makes users of their current location (with respect to the application/website) and the option for further navigation. Breadcrumbs also show hierarchy of the navigation and allows users to navigate higher or lower in the hierarchy.

1. Home
  1. Home
  2. Library
  1. Home
  2. Library
  3. Data

-	Breadcrumbs should not replace global navigation or location navigation (in a section) but complement it.
-	Breadcrumbs should display the current location of the user with respect to hierarchy of navigational structure.
-	Breadcrumb corresponding the current page should not be a link.
-	Breadcrumbs are more useful for application/websites where the hierarchy if deeper than 2 levels. That is, it is not suitable for applications/sites that are have flat hierarchy.
-	Breadcrumb should start with link to home page.

1. Home
  2. Library
  3. Data

När du visar den här webbplatsen eller någon annan webbplats som länkas från den här webbplatsen kan vi spara lite information på din dator i form av en ”cookie”. Scania använder bland annat cookies för att registrera besökarstatistik och för att låta användaren välja språk när han eller hon söker efter ett begagnat fordon på vår webbplats. Du kan ställa in datorn på att blockera cookies. Det innebär dock att vi inte kan garantera att alla delar av webbplatsen fungerar som de ska. Hur du blockerar cookies beror på vilken webbläsare du använder. Välj ”Hjälp” eller en motsvarande meny i webbläsaren om du behöver anvisningar. Kontakt Om du har några frågor, tveka inte att kontakta oss på kontakt@scania.com

These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

A card presents content and actions on a single topic.

Card title

Some quick example text to build on the card title and make up the bulk of the card's content.

Go somewhere

-	Easy to understand content about a topic
-	Consider cards as an entry point to more details
-	Keep the content simple and easy to understand
-	Not all cards are to be clickable. When a card is clickable, the resulting action should be an expected outcome – to navigate to more details for example.

![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/c905d0745db748d09041fcc56998f4e7.PNG)

**Do**  - Use F pattern with call for action on the left bottom side

**Don’t**  - Use Z pattern with call of action on the right bottom side.

The typeface that we use in our internal and external communication is called Scania Sans. The typeface comes in a few cuts; Regular, Bold, Italic, Headline, Headline Bold as well as Condensed, Condensed Bold and a Condensed Italic versions. The typeface is an important part of how the Scania brand is communicated.

Scania Sans Regular
Scania Sans Bold
Scania Sans Italic

ид ест сонет малорум легимус Scania Sans Condensed

-	User roman numerals to indicate pages.
-	When working with high number of pages, links to go forward and backward along with links for first and last page to be shown.

Scania Digital Design System is designed to assist developers in providing sustained optimal velocity in their work. To get this advantage, please have a look at the [component section](components) where you can find code blocks for most of the UI components (if not all) being used in digital solutions across Scania.

Additionally, Scania Digital Design System also continues to offer access and support to Corporate UI with ongoing responsibility of its maintenance.

As you can imagine, such resources are in constant need of upgradation and therefore the Scania Design System encourages [contribution](contribution) from Scania development community.

# Setup for Corporate-UI and Scania-Theme This is a tutorial how to setup a project with Corporate-UI components with Scania-theme styling. Corporate UI is a toolbox with **UI components** that makes it easier to use reusable and modular components for your application. For examples, header, footer, buttons, and dropdowns. Scania-theme is a package that contains Scania specific styling for everyone of those components in Corporate UI toolbox. Every component has a unique styling with Scania look and feel. ## Components Header,footer or a button are all components in our Design System, the difference between them is how they technically made. `` is a web component, while a `` is a regular HTML element that already exist in the HTML Standard. One easy thing to differentiate between those is by looking at the dash in the element name, for example "c-header", that indicates it is a web-component. A web component can be used in the same way as a regular element in the HTML standard. Difference is what is under the hood. You can read more about it here https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Web_Components All web-components in Scania digital design system have namespace with `` ## Audience This is for developers working with web application and have knowledge about web development. Components are available for **react**,**angular** and **vue** We have setup a few example repositories for react, angular and vue - [React]() - [Angular]() - [Vue]() ## Stencil To be able to create a component in Corporate-Ui you need to understand what tool we are using to make it happened. We are using a **Web Component compiler** called [StencilJS](https://stenciljs.com/docs/introduction). This is the core for our components and how we build them. You can read more in Stencil documentation. StencilJS contains features like: - Virtual DOM - TypeScript - JSX Example component: ```javascript import { Component, Prop, h } from '@stencil/core'; @Component({ tag: 'my-component', }) export class MyComponent { // Indicate that name should be a public property on the component @Prop() name: string; render() { return (

My name is {this.name}

); } } ``` ## Prerequisties - Node.js 8 and up(Latest stable) - Node packages manager(NPM) for our packages handling - Git installed - [Github]() account access - If you are behind firewall, configure proxy How to install Node you can find in their [documentation]() and same regarding [Npm](https://docs.npmjs.com/) and [Git](). If you are unfamiliar with npm and node, we recommend that you read more about it in their documentation.After Node.js,npm and git is installad, you can continue! Commands to help you see if you have installed these tools: ```bash > node -v v12.18.0 ``` ```bash > npm -v 6.4.1 ``` ```bash > git --version git version 2.17.0.windows.1 ``` If you come across any problems during this installation guide or feel something needs to be more clear, please contact us our report a issue in our [github]() ## How to use Corporate-ui and Scania-theme Do the following steps: Install Corporate-UI and Scania-theme in your project, this will install the latest version that is published on npm. ```bash > cd > npm i corporate-ui > npm i scania-theme ``` You need to import ` { addTheme, defineCustomElements } ` from Corporate-Ui package and ` { theme } ` from Scania-theme package after you haver installed them (See section Installing npm packages). ### React 1. In React you can go to src/index.js and import the packages Corporate-Ui and Scania-theme. ```Javascript import { addTheme, defineCustomElements } from 'corporate-ui' import { theme } from 'scania-theme' ``` 2. You need to call `defineCustomElements()` ```Javascript defineCustomElements(); ``` 3. After that you need to call `addTheme()` , this function takes one parameter, which is the theme from Scania-theme packages that you imported in step 1. ```Javascript addTheme(theme) ``` ### Angular 1. In Angular, go to **main-ts**(or some other appropriate place), and import the packages Corporate-Ui and Scania-theme. ```Javascript import { AppModule } from './app/app.module'; import { environment } from './environments/environment'; //Import for Corporate-Ui and Scania-theme import { defineCustomElements, addTheme } from 'corporate-ui' import { theme } from 'scania-theme' ``` 2. Angular doesn't recognize what a stencil component is, so what you need to do to solve this is to add `CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA` inside app.module.ts ```Javascript import { NgModule, CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA} from '@angular/core'; @NgModule({ declarations: [ AppComponent, ], imports: [ BrowserModule ], providers: [], bootstrap: [AppComponent], schemas: [CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA] // Add the Schema }) ``` 3. Inside **main.ts**, You need to call `defineCustomElements()` ```Javascript defineCustomElements(); ``` 4. After that you need to call `addTheme()` , this function takes one parameter, which is the theme from Scania-theme packages that you imported in step 1. ```Javascript addTheme(theme) ``` ### Vue 1. In Vue, go to **main.js** and import the packages Corporate-Ui and Scania-theme ```Javascript import Vue from 'vue' import App from './App.vue' //Import Corporate-Ui and Scania-theme import { addTheme, defineCustomElements } from 'corporate-ui' import { theme } from 'scania-theme' ``` 2. In the **main.js** you also need to tell the application to ignore custom-element tags such as `` by adding this line. Otherwise a warning will be thrown in the console. ```Javascript //Ignore all components custom-elements named c-* Vue.config.ignoredElements = [/c-\w*/]; ``` 3. You need to call `defineCustomElements()` ```Javascript defineCustomElements(); ``` 4. After that you need to call `addTheme()` , this function takes one parameter, which is the theme from Scania-theme packages that you imported in step 1. ```Javascript addTheme(theme) ``` ## Add theming When former step (How to use Corporate-Ui and Scania-Theme) is done, you can start adding theme to get the styling. Try and add `` component high up in the hierarchy of your application. for example app.js in react. If it works you should see fonts and so on change. ```Javascript // React example function App() { return (
// Add Theme like this for the styling
); } ``` ## Add header,content and footer After theme is added(Add theming) is done, you can add components ``,`` and `` in that order. After that you should see the header and footer. Content component will push down the footer below the content. ```Javascript // React example function App() { return (
// Add Header,content and footer component // Application content
); } `

pageStructure.title: Migration guide from V3 to V4

content.title: Corporate UI Migration Guide v3 to v4

sections.description:
# Corporate UI Migration Guide v3 to v4
## Before update [Installation guide](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development) Check out [Bootstrap migration guide](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/migration/) for the things you need to apply to your project. You can find out more about Bootstrap 4 JS [here](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/getting-started/javascript/)
## Migration guide checklist `` - c-corporate-header >> c-header - c-main-navigation >> c-navigation - c-main-content >> c-content - c-corporate-footer>> c-footer - c-social-media is deprecated, use c-icon instead to generate social media icons' Check out all components guideline in corporate-ui 4.0 [See all available components](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components) Example: ```html global ``` Example: ```html home user ``` In corporate-ui v3, dealer header component was used as a variation in the c-corporate-header. It is now a separated component. Use `c-dealer-header` instead. [Read more documentation here](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components/header) FontAwesome is no longer provided in corporate-ui. Replace FontAwesome with your own FontAwesome license or replace with our new icon set. [See all available Scania icons](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/foundation/icons)

## Troubleshooting

**If you can't clone (Timeout, access for example)**

    - Check so the URL is correct
    - Are you behind a firewall, configure proxy (4xx error, unable to access)

**Errors install packages with** `npm install`

    - Using recommended Node version. `node -v`
    - Using recommended NPM version. `npm -v`
    - Are you behind a firewall, configure proxy (4xx error, unable to access)
    - Check which version of those packages you are trying to download, if it exist on npm

**Error in creating a link locally with** `npm link`

    - Correct packages name on the npm link
    - Have you cloned Corporate Ui and/or Scania-Theme

**Missing component or styling**

    - Do you have **Scania-theme installed**
    - Are you using `<c-theme></c-theme>` component
    - Check so styling isn't overriden by anything
    - You created npm link with scania-theme and corporate-ui
    - Call `defineCustomElements()` and `addTheme()` from Corporate-Ui package
    - Some version of corporate-ui and scania-theme isn't compatible together
    - Have you set global attribute to true on `<c-theme global=true>`
    - Have you set the name attribute to scania(or if you have your own theme) `<c-theme name='scania'>`
    - Is everything you are using in the component compatible with the browser, you can check [caniuse.com](caniuse.com)
    - Are you using correct version of Corporate-Ui or Scania-theme, some versions might not contain what you are looking for
Modals assist users in completing a task that requires an action by the user.

Modal title

Modal body text goes here.

-	Focus – modals requires user’s full attention and therefore, the focus needs to shift to the modal to enable user interaction.
-	Users need to take action about a modal – either to take action or to cancel/dismiss it
-	Models should not launch other modals
-	do not use scrolling with a modal as far as possible


![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/27b6085ba7de45bc863a0f398be97afc.PNG)

Title – title of the Modal to summarise its purpose
Content – what the user should focus on? provide a clear and concise explanation
Buttons – Use Z pattern with call for action located on the bottom right side.

Modal title

Modal body text goes here.

In the Components section you can see the building blocks of the Scania Digital Design System for building user interfaces aliged with the Scania Brand. 
Each Component provides a solution to a specific UI problem and such components are presented with a visual example together with their specific usage guideline and code example.

The content component is a technical solution to ensure the footer is pushed down in a page. It is important to wrap your content inside this component to ensure the footer never slides up the page if the content is not long enough.
